150940106.review:
I am forced to write a review for a game to check one of the tasks for the Steam Awards 2023. I have chosen this game as I already have 587 hours as of the moment, as well as finished all the achievements. Note that I bought a lot of stuff from this game so I might have it easier due to bonuses and the OP Speed Dating function.

Update: Dang, write a review for a game [i] you have voted, [/i] why you do dis.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[b] – Simple idle-clicker game : [/b] A simple game, really. Clicking things for love points, give certain gifts, and manage your limited stamina. You can leave the game for it to accumulate points and money, if you’re okay with it.

[b] – Loveable characters : [/b] The boys have their own unique personality along with quirks. The voice-acting does it justice. And you can make them give you your birthday gift (or boxers for F2P).

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[b] - Repetitive : [/b] You can only reach so far with time. You need to reset to accumulate multipliers, unlock more characters to increase multipliers, then reset AGAIN. Time is an expensive resource, and you may want to just exchange it with money.

[b] – Needs autoclicker : [/b] If you really want to get all the achievements in-game, you need to have a sturdy mouse and hand, or an auto-clicker, to click your way through Lover+100 for the lategame characters. But for steam achievements, I think average human patience is enough.

[b] – Static CGs: [/b] I was onboarded on the game before their ads took over the gray internet, but man, I wish it was animated. Especially the final scenes. Or just the seasonal CGs.

[b] – Artstyle : [/b] I’m not an artist myself, but the background of some CGs mismatch the artstyle of the characters. This is evident in the seasonal CGs, as it proves to be quite distracting, and you might think they’d just get some random background and paste their drawn character there.

Overall, if you are willing to support them, as their goods are quite reasonable, or just play it for time-killing, then go for it. #CashewMain

148369224.review: From someone who regrets wasting too many hours on a 'free-to-play' game, Blush Blush also suffers the same problem as Crush Crush does. Pushing premium currency so players wouldn't miss out on characters and/or outfits that are on a limited time window. A better alternative would have been by just selling DLC character/outfit packets within the Steam store itself directly. I rather wait longer for a group packet than an individual character that is recently announced in a small time window. The art and writing for some of the characters and pin-ups are mild improvements, however it doesn't save the game from the lack-luster parody characters that are dead-ringers to their official I.P. counterparts and celebrities. This game unfortunately doesn't get that much attention than Crush Crush, so the variety and amount of characters you receive in game is not as much. Both Blush Blush and Crush Crush could've had the potential to be decently fun clicker games if they weren't Free-to-play games at all, and are just sold as any full-price game with DLC character/outfit packets purchasable in Steam directly. No one is immune to micro-transactions and regrettably neither am I. Give this game a pass.

147542423.review:
This game is hard-carried by the cute character designs and art. I'm not too familiar with this style of game or if this is common with them, but with what I've played so far I feel there's a bit too many design decisions made / systems in place designed to really make you want to pull your wallet out, in an unsavory way. 

I know the devs gotta make money but gosh it can feel so annoying to constantly hit those walls where you know you pretty much don't have a *real* option to get to the next stage on a boy's meter unless you reset and wait a while or spend real money in some fashion to speed things up. That just sucks the fun out of the game, and there isn't a tremendous amount gameplay-wise to *love* to begin with. 

I'm tempted enough to maybe keep playing for the sake of seeing more of the cute boys, but it's just unfortunate they're tied to such a frustrating gameplay setup and this specific flavor of iffy monetization. I'm not new to games with microtransactions, but how each game handles that stuff varies; some are ultimately very comfy even as a no-or-low spender, some feel like they're trying at every turn to take your money, and it feels Blush Blush falls a bit too much in the latter camp.

Title: Blush Blush: A Captivating and Saucy Adventure

Introduction:
Blush Blush by Panda Studios is a delightful and saucy game that has won my heart with its charming characters and engaging gameplay. As someone who appreciates relaxing time-passing games with intriguing stories and eye-catching characters, Blush Blush has become a favorite guilty pleasure. From the alluring Ichigo to the unique monsters, this review will explore the game's enchanting world and provide constructive feedback to make the experience even more enjoyable.

Captivating Characters and Engaging Stories:
One of the standout features of Blush Blush is its captivating characters, particularly the charming Ichigo. Each character has a unique personality and backstory, adding depth to the game's narrative. The engaging stories and interactions with the characters make for an immersive experience that keeps players invested in their virtual relationships.

Saucy Elements Done Right:
Blush Blush unabashedly embraces its saucy side, and I must admit that it's done tastefully and with a good dose of humor. The game strikes a perfect balance, making the saucy moments enjoyable and playful without being overtly explicit. This approach adds to the game's charm and keeps players entertained without crossing any uncomfortable boundaries.

Relaxing Time-Passing Gameplay:
Blush Blush offers a perfect escape from the real world with its relaxing and casual gameplay. The simplicity of the clicker mechanics combined with the engaging stories creates an enjoyable experience for unwinding and passing the time. The game doesn't demand constant attention, making it ideal for short bursts of entertainment throughout the day.

Eye-Catching and Unique Characters:
The character design in Blush Blush is undeniably eye-catching. Each character boasts a unique appearance, personality, and charm. The diverse cast of characters allows players to find someone they can truly connect with, fostering a sense of attachment and investment in the virtual relationships.

Constructive Feedback for Enhancements:
While Blush Blush excels in many areas, there are a few areas where it could be enhanced to provide an even more enjoyable experience. The addition of more character development and interactions would further enrich the game's narrative and foster stronger connections with the characters. Furthermore, additional content updates or events could keep players engaged and excited for new adventures with their favorite characters.

Conclusion:
Blush Blush by Panda Studios is an enchanting and saucy game that offers a delightful escape into a world of charming characters and engaging stories. As a fan of relaxing time-passing games with unique and appealing characters, Blush Blush has undoubtedly become a go-to favorite. The tasteful incorporation of saucy elements adds to the game's allure and makes it a true guilty pleasure.

I wholeheartedly recommend Blush Blush to those who appreciate games with endearing characters, intriguing narratives, and a touch of sauciness. The game is perfect for those seeking a casual and immersive experience that allows for a relaxing escape from the real world. Panda Studios has crafted a gem that has undoubtedly found a special place in the hearts of players like me. Keep up the fantastic work and continue enchanting players with your captivating creations!

I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

142582901.review:
I will admit, I somewhat like this game, but there are a lot of issues with it that make me not want to recommend this to others
I'll start with some positives. The art is brilliant and beautiful, especially the introductory cards to each character, and the message pictures. The music is repetitive, but even so, I often find myself vibing to it, and sometimes even humming along. It's just super upbeat
Admittedly, the characters are physically attractive, which is the main appeal of the game, so I'll give it credit for that, it's done its job there
I also very much enjoy spotting little Easter eggs in the illustrations
However, the gameplay itself is where it falls short for me. It's one of those idle games that lulls you into a false sense of progress, making you feel like you're doing something when in fact, the things you do make a minimal impact on your progress. The level barriers start out nice and achievable, then very quickly devolve into something that could take days for you to achieve, even if you try breaking it down, but even then it can still feel tedious. I've found myself stuck on the same point of the game over and over due to how ridiculous it gets at a certain point, with level requirements taking weeks to reach. I understand that, as an idle dating simulator, you're supposed to sit and wait around while the game works offline, but the whole purpose is defeated when the idleness can deter me from making any progress for weeks on end
Which brings me into my next point: the eventual plateau of progress can be a point where most people would use gems to buy speed boosts, but gems become difficult to achieve when you're hardly making progress, and take forever to build up to the amount you need, so unless you're hoarding them from the very beginning, the only other option to build up your gems is money
Many aspects of this game eventually fall into Pay To Play, as the store offering gems or speed boosts or time skips becomes very alluring if you've been left impatiently waiting to achieve one small thing for over a week 
I would also like to add that this doesn't feel like a dating simulator, just a kiss-fest at best

If you're an impatient person, or just don't want to get sucked into another Pay To Play game, I wouldn't play this, it isn't worth it
But if you're just looking for hot men that are just furries deep down, you found your game, I know I have, go nuts (no pun intended)

142302587.review: Just to get it out of the way: the boys *are* cute and I *do* want to kiss them. That's not my issue with the game, and this isn't that kind of negative review. My criticism here is that, when I pick up an idle game, I expect to be able to make slow but steady progress throughout the game until I eventually reach the end of content, even without purchasing in-game boosts. (I even pay upfront for idle games sometimes.) But in this case, the speed of progress slows down so dramatically, even considering the prestige mechanics, that you are essentially required to start buying boosts after a certain point, and with that in mind, I can't help but interpret this as just a gay furry version of any other free-to-play mobile phone trap, where it hooks you on the rush of progress and then expects you to pay up for more doses. If you have lots of money to burn, and you like kissing boys, this is probably for you, but I can't reasonably recommend this to anyone else.

137403429.review:
While it's a fun game, it's a game that's often overlooked by the devs and loses its potential. The animation quality is better than the studios wellknown Crush Crush, and has a very fun, interesting story that encourages you to keep playing, but it's much more rigorous than Crush Crush, and doesn't have a good payoff for it.
 You'll be clicking twice as much for those level ups, and for some reason, they don't have that special "If you rank up with more characters, the clicking won't take as long".
If you're hoping for any of the phone flings or parallel events (for which there are none) to be more characters, forget about it. They VERY RARELY have voting for more phone fling characters, and don't exactly have more phone flings to begin with once you finish them all.
Essentially, once you finish with the main cast (And maybe decide to buy the DLC characters which I did), there's no reason to keep playing.
 This game is very neglected and rarely talked about. If you're someone that likes Crush Crush but has an interest in men instead, this game is good for you, but it's fun up until the point it isn't. 
 The only special events they have now is more DLCs to buy or special outfits for characters that have gotten multiple outfits already. 
 
 I should confirm, I do love this game, the characters are a lot of fun and the artwork is worth playing through, but i'm infuriated at Panda Studios forgetting about this game and only occasionally throwing out outfits while its counterpart gets all the special characters, holiday events, and phone fling voting. It can be as beloved as Crush Crush if they gave it the same hype.

If you like dating sims and idle clicker games, you'll enjoy this.

It has a nice balance of idleness in my opinion as it encourages daily login with events, but they're just 3 clicks and then if you want the extras another 2 clicks after an hour or so when they event extras finish their timer. When you're first starting out the extras may be annoying to claim, but once you've progressed far enough to have enough extra free time blocks they're super easy. To give a good balance whenever you have more time, you can actually progress through the story instead of just doing the dailies and spend more time in the game. 

Of course, it is possible to finish the game super quickly if you so desire, but then you'll just be bored and miss out on the fun you can have by progressing through this game slowly.

133829297.review:
After the last bout of video games that I have played and reviewed, I needed a palate cleanser, and for some reason I chose the gay furry weirdness that is [b]Blush Blush[/b]. It was free, I had already downloaded it, and apparently I'd forgotten that it was taking up residence on my hard drive.

The basic synopsis of [i]Blush Blush[/i] is that you "accidentally" turned a bunch of men into [i]manimals[/i], and the only way to turn them back into humans is to get them to fall in love with you. This is all done through what is a convoluted idle game that you can have running for absurd amounts of time. Or you can close it out and come back to it later. Either way, the whole game revolves around juggling an obscene amount of jobs while also keeping up with hobbies so that you can buy expensive things for your prospective furry harem.

I feel like I have things to complain about, but I also really don't. The dialog is silly yet entertaining. The economy of this game is in shambles and it apparently costs thousands of dollars to go out to eat; millions if you want to buy sunglasses. That altogether makes the whole game just a bit more absurd, and I can't say I haven't enjoyed the time I have spent participating in this broken system. Now, given that this is an idle game, the basic cycle revolves around reaching a hitherto unspecified precipice of wealth/admiration from these [i]manimals[/i] and then resetting the entire game back to zero to gain a boost in the speed at which everything collects. It's basic idle game mechanics.

131191302.review:
I recently tried the game Blush Blush and it is nothing more than a complete waste of time. It pretends to be a game with an interesting premise and cute characters but in reality it's just an annoying phone game that exploits its players with slow game play and manipulative micro-transactions to get you to pay money. It's a shame because I thought the game had potential, but it was all for nothing.

The game centers around a curse that has befallen 12 hot guys and it's up to you to break the curse through love. It sounds like a potentially interesting narrative but it's really just a bunch of uninspired stock stereotypes from jocks, to athletes to academics, to the bad boy and the nice guy. Even though you supposedly have to save these guys, you don't get to interact with them in any meaningful way. Instead, the game just throws a bunch of situations at you and you just have to click through it. 

And of course, like all "Free to Play" games, once you get to a certain point you start to hit a paywall. You have to wait real world hours and days for skills to complete or unlock, or you can buy gems with real money in the store. It's pretty obvious what the developers are trying to do and it's a pretty shady way to make money. 

To make matters worse, there isn't nearly enough nudity in the game. I mean, if you're going to make a game that centers around hot guys, then you should at least give us some gratuitous nudity to enjoy. Instead, you have to buy the DLC to get any kind of real hentai scenes. It's just ridiculous. I don't know why the developers would limit our enjoyment of the game like that.

Overall, I would strongly advise you to stay away from Blush Blush. It does nothing to reward its players and instead just tries to squeeze money out of them. It's not worth the time or money, so just don't bother.

Overall, my opinion of the game is mixed (or should I say MYXed), leaning towards positive. The characters are well designed, some of their banter and catchphrases are cute, funny, and downright *hot* (well, as hot as a cartoon can be) at times. It's cool to see the guys' personalities change as you romance them, and how the characters mesh and break away (well, mostly mesh) well-known tropes and archetypes (i.e. gamer, loner, romantic, stalker, simple but caring, etc.). 

My MAJOR problem with the game is that it takes FOREVER to complete. I've earned and purchased diamonds, time boosts, and DLC characters which have partially accelerated the game, but some of the expectations for this game are ridiculous, especially when you've unlocked most of the characters. The game requires you to reset your progress over and over again to accelerate how quickly time passes, and this becomes especially frustrating when certain characters necessitate a certain amount of reset points to level up. Some characters are nearly impossible to level up because of this. [spoiler]The final main-game character that you unlock, Scale, requires 1,000x reset points to level him up ONCE, which is absurd and tiring from a gameplay perspective.[/spoiler]

That being said, Blush Blush will eat up all your time. All of it. It always gives you just enough to keep you coming back for more. And more. Help? I'm still clicking here.

[td][b]Review in under a minute[/b][/td]
[td][b][i]Blush Blush[/i][/b] was my very first attempt at playing an "idle" game, the kind of game that for the most part plays itself with some occasional imput frm the player. This concept is still something I struggle with, especially being the kind of person who wants full control over the games he plays. I came away from [b][i]Blush Blush[/i][/b] with the strong notion that these idle games are most definitely not made for me. In [b][i]Blush Blush[/i][/b] your character is somehow responsible for a curse that has befallen 12 hawt dudes and turned them into a variety of animals. It is now up to you to naturally break each curse through the power of love. Your end goal is freeing each guy and getting them to fall in love with you (all of whom come from your stock stereotype  from jocks, to athletes to academics, to the bad boy, the nice guy etc. etc.). As you progress through each there is not much of a story, rather than the game placing you in situations - some cute, some awkward. Being "Free to play" at one point your progression with the boys will slow down drastically as mobile mechanics start to raise their ugly head where you have to wait real world hours and days for skills to complete or unlock. This of course can be sped up by purchasing gems with real money in the store. I get that these companies need to make money somehow but these predatory tactics don't sit well with me and this is where I bowed out. Incredibly simple casual game that unfortunately didn't really hold my attention and I was certainly not going to put the time sink of hours required into it to see it conclude, nor purchase gems to aid that purpose.[/td]

121302121.review:
I'm gonna be honest, I can't in good conscience rec this game. Even if it's free, take my thumbs down as a... wobbly hand gesture. It's bad but could be worse. I'm choosing no because it's a fine game with plenty to do, but it's really not worth even the 18+ DLC or any of the in game spending. Overall this game has an immense amount of love put into it, but...

The good of the game: It's free, has some events where you can get extra costumes/images for free with an everyday login, and new content keeps coming out. It's really cute at best, the characters in their human (and sometimes their animal, sorry Dimitri) forms are really cute! The art style is very... cartoonish bordering on anime-like, which I can appreciate. There's different little pictures for the dates at each stage of /de-transformation' and little sprites that change as well when you click/talk to them. There's some voice acting (which I muted) and music (that I also muted) (because I just keep this up in the background to time-farm) which can be nice, and each character is really individual from the others. Unless you count like, Nimh and Cashew, but I love the soft boys so I can't complain. The game is a good time taker if anything, something to run in the background (or it keeps collecting when you've exited the game which is REALLY nice) and to check up on once in awhile. The texting honestly adds a lot to the game and I find myself looking forward to that the most, because some of the conversations are downright cute and the 'extra' boys are sweet. I'm sorry Kelby, but I'm only leveling you up to get that sweet, sweet text conversation.

The eh: The voice acting and music. Music gets real old real fast because it's just the same thing looping, and when you have a game you intend your players to play for literal hours, you gotta give some options or unlockable things. The voice acting is cute sometimes, and downright cringey and annoying at others (Eli and his hay joke is burned into my eardrums). The PC can be customized barely in a settings screen, but it has no bearing on your weird marshmallow-like visage in any of the date scenes. The reset-based-speedups are an 'interesting' game mechanic that I only use when I have like, an hour or time I have absolutely nothing else to do with, in order to get all the guys back up to where they were in 'half' the time or something. Honestly I just use a few days to first do all the hobbies, then the rest to do the jobs for money.

The bad: The artwork sometimes, and yeah even the 18+ kind. I'm a grown adult and yeah I got this game for the NSFW reasons, and seriously it is not worth it. The anatomy in some of these pictures (IE Poe's third selfie in the texting...thing) is just really bad and awkward. Honestly? Even the 'lover' portion of each guys de-transformation is the same three images with the same exact poses with very slight differences at most. The writing can be atrocious at times, not even just cringey but Eli's lines sometimes make me go 'what the hell?'. Don't get me started on some of the 'accent-typing' in the game, which could be borderline offensive in some cases. Like, what is Anon? Is he British? Austrailian? Are Garret and Dimitri Russian? Something else? Maybe this would be answered if I turned on the voice acting, but I really can't bring myself to. The game has 'a lot' to do, but it's all based around time. And the numbers you need after certain points (like over one billion hearts to reach lover status with some guys) is ridiculous. Like actually ridiculous. The game turns from kind of fun and quirky to a downright slog. It doesn't matter how many 'resets' you do, you'll always reach a point where getting one level in a hobby will take literally 10 hours. That ain't it. I get it's a time based game, but be reasonable. I'm not paying for the diamonds to boost things that, in the end, won't matter after a certain point in the game. That part is just a blatant cash grab, and I think if dev's halved the time needed/money needed for everything in the game, it would honestly be a LOT better.

TLDR: Play Nu:Carnival if you want something hotter, with better writing (an actual MC, EIden is truly adorable and the lore is actually pretty interesting), and actual... well. Scenes. Blush Blush is fine for free, but if they want people to enjoy the game and spend money, they have to up the quality of... everything, really.

119168037.review:
I recommend this game because I want to support gay-friendly and adult-oriented games. Down with censorship!

That said, I think this will appeal to a good many people. There are cute guys with interesting designs, always some goal to work towards, and plenty of things to interact with. If you like idle games or clickers, this will probably appeal to you.

And [i]that[/i] said, I don't really enjoy it a lot personally, because I don't really like idle games or clickers. There's a whole lot of tedium if you're trying to see all you can see. Even when I have purchased things, I don't even get to use them for an eternity. The reset mechanic, unless you're willing to pay the genuinely valuable currency (which thankfully you usually do get a regular, if small, amount of if you participate in events), seems to make the whole thing feel like kind of a waste of time. It supposedly gives you a boost for things to go faster, but I don't notice that much of a difference, and some of the goals it expects you to achieve are just exercises in boredom and being unable to advance because of a really unreasonable requirement.

I spend more time not playing this game than playing it. I'm not sure if I like that, but it is what it is.

I don't really know how to unlock some of the characters, even if I went to the trouble of getting things for them, though I will say that I have had both really good support and not-so-great support when I wrote in for help. Mileage may vary, and it's understandable. I can't be too harsh on an indie developer with limited resources and people.

The art is cute and colorful, but I don't find it particularly erotic or appealing. The sound is inoffensive, although I really do not care for most of the voices. The sense of humor of the writer or writers isn't very funny to me, either. There are too many attempts at jokes that revolve around either cruelty to animals or just insensitivity. For example, one of the characters says he has a bad heart, to the point that he may have a shortened lifespan -- which is absolutely nothing I want in a sexy, cute game presented as a light experience -- yet they make a seriously unfunny cartoon attempt to make him look like he might have a heart attack when going on the roller coaster event required to advance his familiarity. That makes me feel like a jerk, and it makes me feel the writer is a bigger one. It's not funny to joke about that, dude. I shouldn't have to see that when I'm supposed to be playing a goofy sex game.

Some of the writing is so questionable that the characters might at times come off as gross, though most of them are inoffensive enough, if not particularly appealing. It's easy to see how they might have thought they would hop on a trend, but there's also a pressure to complete things like the phone stories, in order to unlock other characters, though it isn't very clear about how this is even done.

In short, if you think this game might be for you, try the free version and see if the gameplay is something you like. Maybe you'll be on the same wavelength as the humor in this game. Maybe you like clickers and idle games. If so, you'll be right at home here. If you don't have a powerful love of those sorts of games, though, you might want to try something else. I do recommend supporting adult games for mature audiences, casual or otherwise, especially gay-friendly ones, and I'd like to see many more that do things better than this one, but this is one of the only ones we have.

So, if you think you might enjoy it, give it a try and then maybe support the release with the uncensored art. It should be released that way anyway, but just consider the free version a demo, I suppose. Hopefully, we'll see more games of this type, and when we do, there will be more likelihood of ones that broader audiences will be able to engage with and find enjoyable.

118878547.review:
EDIT: Okay, after long deliberation (and uninstalling the game--what the hell happened to me when I was playing this for like two weeks?!) I've decided to change my recommendation to a clear NO unless this is your kind of game or you feel comfortable busting out the dollar bills so you can scrape ahead of the fray.

After quite a while of keeping this game idling or using an auto-clicker to get my jobs done, I realized something--there is no "quick system" in place to get things done.

If you've played the game and gotten to the last 2-3 guys you'll understand what I mean. Suddenly they're asking for 6,666,666,666 of an item, but the maximum you can buy at one time is 1 million. So basically, you'll find yourself clicking over [i]70,000 times[/i] to complete one task. And it's not just clicking in one spot, oh no, you have to actually move your mouse, the horrors! This gets very annoying very fast.

And all for what, the same quippish lines and almost-nudity and micro-transaction begging? It's just not worth it. In five clicks, I can rip the images from this game for free or look it up online. It might make you say, [i]what's the point of any clicker game, then,[/i] well... I'm playing [i]Cookie Clicker[/i] and having bounds more fun with its gimmicks than I ever did playing [i]Blush Blush[/i] and setting my computer clock 50 years in the future just to level up my jobs and stuff in the later stages.

So, uh, if you have a lot of time on your hands, I guess it's perfectly fine. If you're like me and still require your hand, wrist, and forearm to work for anything more worthy of your time, just skip it and play something that gets automated after a while, like [i]Cookie Clicker[/i] or [i]Egg Inc.[/i] And don't fall for micro-transaction temptations.

Keeping my original review below for anyone curious...

---

[i]Blush Blush[/i] is a click-a-thon/tap-a-thon soft-reset level-building game. If you've played games like [i]Cookie Clicker[/i] (gosh, remember when that was just a silly browser game?) or [i]Egg Inc.[/i] on mobile, it's that, just with little guys.

It's... your typical guy-laden game fare. You have one for each stereotype. The shy guy, the "tsundere" guy (i-it's not like I like you or anything! You know what I mean.), the sports guy, the gay guy, the gamer guy, etc. etc. ad nauseam. What sets [i]Blush Blush[/i] apart from the fray is its insistence upon meta and self-aware humor (wait, are the other games doing that, too? Beats me, I usually uninstall these within a few hours, if not a few minutes).

Honestly, if you just want something brainless to click on, it's perfectly serviceable. That's what this game is for. That's why I say I "recommend" this game. But it's also why I'll judge it harshly coming up:

- The idling requirements are INSANE. Yes, it's a soft-reset game, meaning you can rack up reset points and get multipliers on everything, but seriously, when your hobbies start hitting the mid-30s mark, even with a 30x multiplier, it can take literal [i]days[/i] to get to the next level. Yes, days plural. Higher level players report similarly when it gets up to 40s and 50s (the max level for each hobby is 70). This will be a huge turn-off for casual players who just want to see all the guys. Though, I suppose you could just look them up on Google, or shuffle through the game files... Similarly, some future guys require you to have a certain reset multiplier The first one who asks for this asks for, like, 20? The next, 100. Jesus! Whatever, if you know how to change the date on your computer, you can skip ahead 7 days in the game. You don't even have to close it.

- I understand that as the "guy rank" increases, the demands for future guys will be higher, but seriously--having to click a hundred times to satisfy a date requirement is really stupid. It makes me wish there was an "autofill" checkbox, where the game would continue to act as if you clicked the "go again" button until the requirement was fulfilled. I can sit there and wait for the hundred dates to finish after a minute or two. I hate having to keep clicking away like some kind of Sisyphian task.

- Oh, and this one might go without saying: don't play a game like this if you're sensitive to gambling, AKA you have an itchy buyer's finger. You might find yourself compelled to purchase a pack of diamonds (the premium currency) or to pick up a few of the DLC boys. Hey, I know, a developer's gotta make money--though I'd say locking away QoL changes like, oh, [i]an autofill button that lets you clear out some absurd requirement like 100 dates in one click,[/i] behind a purchase is kind of a jerk move. But hey, that's just my opinion, and who am I to judge? The game is free, after all.

If this is your kind of jam, give it a shot. The art's pleasing and the jokes got a chuckle out of me sometimes.

118538287.review:
Humans are classified in the sub-group of primates known as the Great Apes.

Humans are primates, but the primates that we most closely resemble are the apes. We are therefore classified along with all other apes in a primate sub-group known as the hominoids (Superfamily Hominoidea).

This ape group can be further subdivided into the Great Apes and Lesser Apes. Humans have bodies that are genetically and structurally very similar to those of the Great Apes and so we are classified in the Great Apes sub-group which is also known as the hominids (Family Hominidae).

Humanoid Skulls
Male Chimpanzee, Pan troglodytes, Skull
Ape diversity
The first apes evolved about 25 million years ago and by 20 million years ago were a very diverse group. Within the last 10 million years, however, many ape species became extinct as the earth’s climate cooled and dried and their forested environments changed to woodland and grassland. There are now only about 20 living species of apes and they are divided into two major groups. These are the:

Lesser Apes, containing the gibbons
Great Apes, containing the orang-utans, gorillas, chimpanzees and humans
Ape features
Apes (including humans) possess the same general features that all primates share but they differ from other primates in a number of distinctive ways.

Features that separate the apes from other groups of primates include:

a brain that is larger and more complex than other primates
distinctive molar teeth in the lower jaw which have a ‘Y5’ pattern (five cusps or raised bumps arranged in a Y-shape)
a shoulder and arm structure that enables the arms to freely rotate around the shoulder
a ribcage that forms a wide but shallow chest
an appendix
no external tail
The Lesser Apes
There are about 14 species of relatively small-bodied apes known as Lesser Apes. These are the gibbons, which live in trees, rarely descend to the ground and are active during the day. Gibbons are found in the forests of South-east Asia.

The gibbons have the following features:

body size which is similar in males and females
bodies adapted for living in trees which they rarely leave. These adaptations include very long arms with a shoulder structure that enables them to rapidly swing from one branch to the next and long curved finger and toe bones to powerfully grip tree branches
hardened pads of skin (callosites) on their buttocks for prolonged sitting
a diet of fruit or leaves
long, pointed canine teeth and long jaws
a social lifestyle consisting of small family groups consisting of an adult male-female pair and their juvenile offspring
The Great Apes
The Great Apes are named for their large bodies. They also have larger brains than other primates. Like Lesser Apes, the Great Apes are active during the day. There are four types of Great Apes – the orang-utans, gorillas, chimpanzees and humans.

Orang-utans

There are two living species of orang-utan – the Bornean Orang-utan, Pongo pygmaeus, and the Sumatran Orang-utan, Pongo abelii. Orang-utans live in dense rainforests of Borneo and Sumatra in South-east Asia.

Orang-utans have the following features:

considerable sexual dimorphism in which the males are about twice as big as the females
bodies adapted for living in trees which they rarely leave and also for quadrupedal (four-legged) movement on the ground. These adaptations include very long arms with a shoulder structure that enables them to move slowly from branch to branch (especially in young, lighter bodied orang-utans) and long curved finger and toe bones to powerfully grip tree branches
a diet of fruit supplemented by insects
long, pointed canine teeth and long jaws
occasional use of tools, such as twigs and sticks
a solitary lifestyle except when breeding or when mothers have offspring
Gorillas
There are two living species of gorilla – the Western Gorilla, Gorilla gorilla, and the Eastern Gorilla, Gorilla beringei. Gorillas live in dense forests in western and central tropical Africa. Gorillas are the largest of all primates. Their features include:

considerable sexual dimorphism in which the males are about twice as big as the females
bodies adapted for climbing trees (when young) and also for quadrupedal (four-legged) movement on the ground. These adaptations include arms and shoulders that enable them to swing from branch to branch (in lighter bodied, young gorillas); finger and toe bones that are long and curved for gripping tree branches and strongly built to support their large body weight; and knuckle walking’, in which they support themselves on the knuckles of their hands.
a diet of fruit, leaves and shoots
long, pointed canine teeth and long jaws
a social lifestyle in which about 10–20 individuals live in small, permanent groups
Chimpanzees

There are two living species of chimpanzee – the Common Chimpanzee, Pan troglodytes, and the Bonobo or Pygmy Chimpanzee, Pan paniscus. Chimpanzees live in woodland and forests in western and central tropical Africa. Chimpanzees are the smallest of the Great Apes and our closest living relatives. Their features include:

moderate sexual dimorphism in which males are slightly larger than females although this is reduced in Bonobos
bodies adapted for climbing trees and also for quadrupedal (four-legged) movement on the ground. These adaptations include:arms and shoulders that enable them to swing from branch to branch (especially in young, lighter bodied chimpanzees); long, curved finger and toe bones to powerfully grip tree branches; and ‘knuckle walking’, in which they support themselves on the knuckles of their hands.
a diet of fruit supplemented by meat
long, pointed canine teeth and long jaws
frequent use of tools, such as sticks, twigs and stones
complex social groups consisting of a dispersed community containing from 10 to 100 or more individuals that often divide into small foraging groups with a constantly changing membership of about 3–10 individuals
Humans

There is only one living species of human – Modern Humans, Homo sapiens. Humans now live in almost every part of the world.

117240313.review:
Preface: The objective of this review is purely based on my own reasons for playing this game and it taken from the perspective of both mine and another's on the game. Do take some aspects of this review with a grain of salt and sarcasm.

My first preconceptions about this game was it would be another corny "love" simulator. But after playing this game for quite a while since I first got it back in my senior year (yes, online school during the pandemic was boring, who would have guess?), my outlook on this game has greatly shifted.

Yes, this game still follows many of the stereotypes associated with this genre of games. Countless hours of grinding and coming back to the game, somewhat cringe storylines, and very typical love story premises. BUT, the game was able to curve my playing experience by introducing characters I could connect to, having fun side conversations (I'll get to that in a bit) and introducing a wide cast of 'lovers' to find and help out. Without playing the game I had assumed many of the characters would be flat, just like many other games out there, but I was plesantly surprised when I played the game for the first 10 hours and was hooked on the storyline of the first 3 characters I interacted with. I liked the thought that went into designing each manimal as the animal they are transformed into is a subtle hint to what their personality, dynamic and story will progress. Similarly, the game eventually introduces a cellphone for you to interact with to have side conversations with. Many of them are unlocked by progressing the game further along, but are well worth playing through. Just like how there is a diverse cast of manimals, there is an equally diverse cast of people to text and chat with in your phone. I will say that a few of them may or may not be manimals from DLC packs or friends of characters who are turning into manimals, so that is another incentive to do these, for lore reasons (and yes, there are photos in each text storyline you do that are somewhat NSFW).

Without a doubt, I am sure many people would have thought that this game would have only several 'round' characters that play off of stereotypes from real life, but this is far from what is actually presented within the game. Yes, there are points in which the game dose poke fun at guy stereotypes, but not in a serious tone. That is what made the game so interactive for me. Even though at the end of the day this game is still a love simulator, it does still provide some laughs with corny stories and funny characters.

But, as expected, no game can/will be perfect, so let's get on with what are negative with the game. To progress the game, it is very grindy and time consuming, but that is too be expected from free love sims. Although it can be grindy at times, it is much more forgiving with this aspect by introducing various points to 'prestige' and increase your rate of creating money, upgrading skills and so on so fourth. This also becomes a required thing in progressing some of the stories of characters later down the line. This game also requires you to be very active in it in order to participate in various events for 'rare' items that you either can get through another event later down the line or spending real money on it. But once again, let me refute this downside by ellaborating that the game is quite forgiving and has people with busy lives in mind by having events occur daily and providing various opportunities for people to complete past events via gems. And before you saw that gems do require cash, these gems are very different from those in other games outside of the love sim genre even. This gems can be easily aquired through the daily events and even by just progressing the game. But the biggest drawback from my experience was the need for 'time slots.' If you are unfamiliar with this concept within a game, it is basically the open slots you have to complete tasks. Just like how in 'Clash of Clans' you need builders to complete buildings, this game requires you have time slots open for various jobs to help each manimal. The game is a tiny bit forgiving with this concept though by providing various opportunities to obtian more time slots. Unless you are a dedicated gamer and have lots of free time on your hands, I would not recommend buying time slots with real cash. People with more time to spare will be able to easily rack up time slots like it is nothing.

One final thing I would like to add onto this review is the character interactions and stories. Overall, each one of them is enjoyable and funny in their own little ways. Both the main casts and side casts are insightful in their own, individual desires and providing laughs. At first I thought this game was meant to be purely a dating sim, but then I got further along and realized many aspects of it are meant to be funny, corny and cringe. IT breaks the typical mold of sexualized gaming by being inclusive in its characters, interactions, player base and even target audiences.

If you do have some time to spare, even just for 5 mins, just open the game and play it. Don't take things seriously, unless you're just built like that, and strap in for a very interesting ride of emotions.

(And yes, it does have some *spicey* scenes, but that's besides the point.)

Surprisingly addicting! I know that these types of games aren't everyone's cup of tea, and I certainly thought the same when I first learned about the game. I watched a bit of gameplay from a third person perspective (watching my younger sister play it) and was a bit skeptical about the whole premise of the game. After all, it did give off major furry vibes at first glance. Despite this, she insisted that it was fun, so I gave in and decided to give it a shot. And lo and behold, I play it almost daily (even if just for a few minutes) and have progressed deeper than I initially thought I would. For me personally, the game acts as a "filler" or a temporary distraction when I have nothing better to do, and is certainly a way to pass the time. 

As for the contents for the game itself, I'm not totally obsessed, but like it enough to keep playing. The characters are fairly diverse and charming, especially my boy Eli. His "yaas" energy just really resonated with me lol. The whole entire plot of the game is random, but I understand that it's the whole point -- after all, it is meant to be a rather humorous game. There's also the... ahem... "assets" that the game possesses, if that's what some of you are looking for. Overall, I'd say just give it a shot! Who knows, you might end up unexpectedly liking it much like I did.

[h1] An Honest Review [/h1]
I haven't played much of this game but the fact that most of the boys if not all of them are based off a stereotype makes the game 10 times less engaging to me, given that they don't feel like actual characters but rather like a bunch of stereotypes glued together to try to make the simulation of a character with a personality and motives. 

I'm pretty sure that's the fun part of the game: that they're so stereotypical it's funny, but it feels like a negative factor to me, especially given that this is supposed to be a dating sim and a big factor of this type of games is that you can get to deeply know the character, which doesn't happen in this game because they aren't meant to have a deep personality.

So basically: [b] it makes a really good clicker game[/b], especially considering that is free, but I can't personally say the same about the dating sim part.

Maybe I'm asking for too much for a free game, but I wanted to share my opinion anyway.

The game play is okay, but the monthly events can be buggy. I still don't really recommend it because it's repetitive and takes a very long time to just get each guy to "lover" as the "higher tier" require you to have reset the game "x" amount of times instead of just having patience to wait it out for the money / skills. Making the game longer than it needs to be with limited content, also some of the guys are locked behind real money payments that cannot be got around by accumulating diamonds or hoping it might appear as a monthly (which has happened 1 time since I started playing). 

While the "reset" of the game is a unique quirk, to have to do so over and over and over again just to progress is a little annoying and a game that originally had my attention for at least 10 minutes now barely has it for the few minutes it takes to start or end a task for the monthly thing as I have to wait hours / days to accumulate things and I am not anywhere near being able to finish the original cast (not counting the ones behind the pay wall).

116012492.review:
Listen. This game is not super in-depth and it knows it. It's loose, doesn't take itself too seriously, and it knows you're here to date cute guys and not much else. And it does a very good job of providing that specific experience.

The plot is pretty much an excuse - you work at a zoo and accidentally handed out a bunch of cursed water bottles that turned people into talking animals, which can only be undone with true love's kiss. Fortunately, you're poly as fuck and capable of loving all of them at the same time. The identities of the guys only get weirder as time goes on, starting with a cute, sweet boy who got turned into a rabbit and your classic broody damaged wolf-boy, and ultimately ending with a figure-skating vampire cobra and an assassin dragon (who I still haven't actually managed to progress with, but more on that later).

There's also the Phone Flings, a series of guys you can have short text conversations with and collect pictures of. Recently, the devs started taking popularity polls and converting people's favorite text guys into full-on manimals through assorted other forms of magic; the third LTE for a free unlock is ongoing, but they can be bought for 200 gems after the fact as well. Which seems expensive to me, since that's $20 in real money if you get them through microtransactions, but there's worse things than having to pay for extra content and it is possible to get some gems for free if you're very patient.

But be prepared to be VERY patient, and screw with your system date and time a lot. Getting anywhere in this game can take literal decades if you don't, and no one likes that. And some of the requirements for the boys are pretty heavy, especially towards the end of the core 12. Scale has a requirement of a 1,000x reset boost just to get past the introductions stage; I've been playing for over 40 hours and I've just barely scraped 250, with two gem multiplier purchases.

All in all, I'd give this game maybe a 7/10. It knows what it's about and doesn't pretend otherwise, and some of the boys are very fun to be with. Also the paid uncensored edition is fairly solid.

112038113.review:
It's a cute clicker game for sure, and the art's gorgeous! The VA's do a pretty nice job, and in general it's a nice lil game to idle to. Ultimately I do recommend this game, but it also has its fair share of... well, cringe. 

For people new to otome games, I imagine the whole genre can be a little uncanny, but it's easy to get used to if the characters are good and the story's engaging. This game may have a nice story, but some of the characters are..... 'interesting'. The first character who comes to mind is Anon. His character is meant to be a parody of 707 from Mystic Messenger, but GOD does it HURT. Everything about him makes me wanna keel over; from his voice acting, to quoting terrible outdated internet trends, to his little quips here and there. The same thing goes for Ichiban, a parody of Markiplier. Really nice design, but just feels.... like nails on a chalkboard.

However, there are some characters that are really enjoyable. The first two you can unlock are Nimh and Volks, and they have their own respective charm and personality quirks. The point being though, it doesn't feel like they're being shoved down your throat. In general their references are more subtle and digestible compared to Anon, Ichiban, or hell-- even Eli's. 

...But, all things considered, it's a nice game. Those are personally just some issues I had with the game, and they're pretty small. A little tip though: the DLC characters are *chefs kiss* I'm a sucker for Cole.

Good game. I recommend. Also there's a 'gamer' skill lol.

111623864.review:
Gonna start this off by saying I so deeply wish Steam had a "neutral" rating button, bc this is one of those games where I personally didn't enjoy it but I could absolutely respect it, and I could see where other people would absolutely love it. 
The positives: 
I love the character designs and interactions. Every* one of the characters feels different from each other, which means that saving each one of them is a unique experience. The game's beautifully and functionally designed, so props to the devs for making this a joy to look at.
That being said, the negatives: 
Steam didn't flag this as an idle game so I didn't realize until I'd booted it up and gotten hooked into the story that it'd be a "numbers go up when you click" simulator. Not a fault of the devs or the game itself, but I don't think the positives of the game outweigh the drudgery of the genre it's based on. 
Additionally, the game has faults of its own design: I wrote "Every*" because I could only sit through the first 3 characters. The game's difficulty / time requirements ramp up sharply around the time you reach Kelby's 2nd stage, and it quickly became far too slow-paced for my taste, even factoring in the action speed bonus from resets. 
Speaking of that, dates still require you to click to repeat them, it could just be that I didn't progress far enough to unlock a solution, but the lack of automation on that front made it seem like love growth could only ever progress as quickly as one could click to restart dates. I understand the fact that if implimented unconditionally, auto-repeating dates could bankrupt the player, but adding a conditional (eg. 'only do as many dates/sec as income can support') seems like an incredibly easy safeguard. Additionally, I thought the game pushed the store aspect rather heavily. You could probably play the game to completion without spending a cent, but (as with many idle games) the time investment required would likely just turn it into a slog where any joy you get from progression is overshadowed by the sheer glaciality of it.
All in all, Blush Blush is a masterfully-made game with a lot of charming characters and a fun premise, but it suffers from all of the usual flaws of the idle genre, and would work much better as a traditional rpg imo. Unless you're willing to deal with that fact to experience the story, save your time and hard-drive space and either go find somebody else's playthrough of it or skip the game entirely.

Okay so, I haven't actually played this game for 9000+ hours - I just have a bad habit of forgetting to shut the game down.  

That said, this game is enjoyable enough that I wouldn't mind playing it long enough to actually reach 9000+ hours of actual play time at some point. It's simple, not a lot of story, but strangely relaxing for super anxious and stressed out me. Yes there is in-app purchase stuff, but I haven't found that to be necessary to enjoy the game, and it's not required to move your game along if you are smart about soft resets and take advantage of the in-game events.

109075751.review:
Blush Blush is an idler dating sim that is mostly a clicker game. LGBTQ+ friendly and a lot of content, raise your hobby levels to get more hearts per click and increase your jobs and get promotions for more money for gifts. Raising lover levels is rewarded with a better relationship status and eventually outfit unlocks! Go on scenic dates and collect various CG’s! Also featuring Phone Flings, where you can message guys not yet in the game. 

While pretty fun, there is not really anything to do or keep you occupied after you max everything out. Despite coming out in 2019, there is a noticeable lack of new characters, and many of the outfits are locked behind a monthly sign-in reward or you buy them with Gems, which you can earn in game or buy with irl money; so while it is an idler game, you need to sign in at least twice a day to start a count down for your reward, (1hr) and then play again to collect it. Alternatively, ignore it and check in once a week.
Regardless, It’s still an enjoyable game.

106946828.review:
As someone who had never really played any idle/clicker type games before, I decided to give this one a go as it looked up my street. I never really had any intentions to fully commit to it, only intending to play until either I got stuck or lost interest - as of writing this review, I have now booted up this game every day for a full year, & passed the 100 hour mark on a Steam game for the first time ever. A major dark horse for one of my favourite discoveries of 2021 (technically 2020? Started playing it on New Year's Eve...)

For the most part, it's a well-presented, low maintenance game. It features an adorable cast of characters with a fairly broad range of personalities; vibrant, colourful artwork with a lot of cartoony charm; some fun dialogue, if a little repetitive in places (I've noticed more than a few repeated phrases shared between characters); and a daily stamp incentive to receive free rewards. Depending on how patient you are, it's entirely possible to play through this without ever needing to spend on it, though I will say the fully-voiced paid add-on is a must as it really brings the characters to life so much more.

Most of the goodies in this game, save for a couple of the characters & the aforementioned voice DLC (as well as the optional 18+ mode, sold separately) can be acquired with the in-game currency of diamonds, which can be gradually acquired freely via daily rewards or hitting milestones in the game. These can also be bought, if you desire to speed things along a bit; you never really need too many though.

The "phone flings" side feature is really fun; while the experiences are fairly linear, there are occasional dialogue decisions which can slightly adjust your conversations with the various side characters. I like the inclusion of the wait times in this; it helps to build anticipation, & gives you something else to look forward to as you go along. At time of writing, a couple of these have become full-fledged characters in the game; hopefully there will be more to come as time passes.

I've enjoyed my time with this game; collecting the daily stamps makes it very easy to keep your hand in as it only takes up 30-40 seconds of your time to do, then you can get stuck in with making the numbers go up as & when you feel like it. It's reassuring to see it receive ongoing support as well, being a spin-off title to the notably more popular Crush Crush. Well worth giving it a go for free if it looks like something you would enjoy.

Unless you're familiar with reset mechanics and enjoy them, don't play this game. 

I was really hyped for it and bought almost all the DLC on the first day of getting it only to discover that the only possible way to advance is to keep resetting and losing all your progress. It's incredibly annoying and I'm only playing out of a sense of completism/a desire to collect all the boyfriends. It's not fun, though. It feels more like a chore than anything else.

Apart from that, though, the game's great. The art is top notch, the boys so far all have clearly defined characters and the phone convos with random other chars really helps to flesh out the world. If I could just play it normally, I'd be recommending it with ten stars! It's seriously only the reset mechanic (that I have never encountered before) that's making this game a pain.

101668399.review:
He jugado y completado este juego por una apuesta que me hizo mi hermana (una larga historia) además veo que no hay muchas reseñas en español, así que voy aportar mi pequeño granito de arena.
Sin más dilación, vamos allá... ¡¡¡Blush Blush!!!

= Resumen del juego =
En este caso tomaremos el papel de "Marshmallow", este mote se debe a su aspecto pálido y forma de chibi que representa al jugador (¡Mira eres tú!), y trabajas en un zoo repartiendo botellas de agua. Hasta que un día confundes los suministros de agua con los del agua mágica y tus clientes se convierten en animales, el error de todos los días vamos. Llen@ de determinación (y tu despido en el trabajo) decides partir en busca de los manimales (man / hombre + animal) perdidos y restaurarlos a su estado original... ¡CON EL PODER DEL AMOR VERDADERO!

+ Puntos positivos +
+ La historia es un puro desvarío imposible que te la tomes en serio, te acabará doliendo la cabeza o frustrandote si piensas demasiado en ella (lo digo por experiencia propia). Me pregunto que se fumaron Sad Panda Studios para crear este juego (?)
+ El estilo visual del juego es muy colorido / agradable a la vista, y no estoy hablando de los chicos (aunque se nota una gran diferencia si los comparas con los diseños iniciales y los más recientes).

= Puntos neutrales =
= La música no es nada del otro mundo, de hecho la mayoría del tiempo que jugué estuvo en silencio.
= Los diálogos de los chicos están repletos de chistes y juegos de palabras haciendo referencia a los animales que son. Fans están trabajando en la traducción del juego en español, pero me temo que esas secciones van a ser imposibles de adaptar en nuestro idioma (a no ser que sean traducciones literales).

- Puntos negativos -
- Los chicos son mega clichés. Tenemos varios ejemplos: el tímido, el tsundere, el deportista, el fiestero, etc... y solo he descrito a los cuatro primeros.
- Apenas hay interacción (relevantes) con los personajes principales haciendo muy difícil que te encariñes con ellos (no me parece una excusa su atractivo físico), de hecho los contactos de tu teléfono me parecen muchísimo más interesantes que ellos porque tienes conversaciones enteras con ellos (aunque también sean referencias/parodias a la cultura pop).
- El hecho de que no puedas comprar el número de regalos o de citas que el personaje quiera de forma automática (aunque solo sea con un botón) a pesar de tener tiempo o dinero suficiente, me enerva muchísimo sobretodo si lo justifican con la compra de un DLC específico (que añade a un chico extra que te da esa habilidad).
Si es una mejora del juego no la limites, si solo es contenido adicional que no añade jugabilidad pero a otros podrían interesarles entonces adelante (se que los creadores quieran financiar su trabajo y lo comprendo, pero tienen otras opciones de micro transacciones).

= ¿Se puede completar al 100% (logros)? =
Puedes conseguir todos los logros sin necesidad de comprar ningún DLC, pero aviso de que te llevará su tiempo ya que tendrás que maximizar el nivel de todos los trabajos y hobbies, y ser amante de todos los chicos.

= Conclusión (5/10)=
Es un buen clicker (teniendo en cuenta que es gratuito) no lo niego pero no me termina de convencer; el género de romance "con contenido sexual" personalmente me incomoda bastante (aunque estén en ropa interior), empecé con expectativas muchísimo más bajas del juego y me acabó sorprendiendo a veces pero no me vais a volver a ver jugando esto.

Quitando todos mis problemas personales, si te gustan los clickers y quieres sentirte como una princesa Disney besando animales para que se conviertan en chicos guapos este es tu juego.
Espero haber sido de ayuda. Chao chao~ (^^)/

100934021.review:
Sweet-natured, good humoured game with a little bit of sauciness; corny but endearing jokes, cute guys with a variety of personality types, solid voice-acting....the overall product is well worth the asking price.  The only downside is the *ridiculously* over-inflated click-based 'playtime' required for unlocking any of the later guys and their further levels.  Even after resetting multiple times to build up 10,000x or more acceleration multipliers, it still takes thousands upon thousands of individual clicks to raise levels high enough to unlock all content.  There doesn't seem to be much of a good reason for this other than artificially stretching out the content by outright blocking progress- even outright buying your way to victory doesn't significantly reduce the timesink necessary....or save the poor computer mouse.

So, on the whole, nice game, lovely content, stretched too thin over irritating progression mechanic.

Anyways. The game is visually well put together, very child-like anime style. Just not my kind of gameplay.
